title: Will artificial intelligence kill jobs in the future? - Quora

response.answer_text: Even though this question has been answered by many people, I’m going to take a stab at injecting some optimism here, since the pessimism that is expressed in many of the answers belie what has historically been the impact of novel technologies. One does not need to look very far: this week, we are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the world wide web. Folks like me, who went to graduate school in the 1980s, remember all too well what the world was like, when there was no WWW. No social networks, no easy access to scholarly papers, no streaming of music or movies, only physical newspapers, and so on and so forth. A social networking site like Linked In, which now has over 150 million members just from the US, did not exist 30 years ago. Linked In now makes it possible to run all sorts of statistics on job creation, and it should be a relatively simple project to data mine Linked In to see how many jobs were created by technologies like WWW, or data science. Linked In, for example, estimates that just in the San Francisco Bay Are, the estimated shortage of data scientists is over 30,000! LinkedIn Workforce Report | United States | August 2018 The Internet came to life for the common man and woman with the invention of the Web. Has the web been a “job killer”? Most people would find that a ridiculous idea. Literally millions of jobs have been created over the past three decades in categories that never existed before: web designers, cloud computing engineers, e-commerce specialists, and many other jobs that were simply not possible before have emerged. There are about 20 million developers over the world, which is probably a guesstimate, and it’s quite likely that more than 10% of these folks are essentially web-based software developers: Just how many darned developers are there in the world? GitHub is puzzled AI will undoubtedly create tens of millions of new jobs, in many new categories of work that simply don’t exist. As a simple example of this need, take the increasing use of humans to label images for self-driving cars: for example, just one San Francisco company called Scale raised about $20 million for providing human-labeled images, and it is one of scores of such companies: Scale raises $18 million to label data from autonomous car companies like Lyft and Embark Multiply this job category over tens of thousands of job categories, where supervised learning is applicable and requires massive amounts of labeled data, and it is not far fetched to estimate that as many as a million human labelers may be needed over the coming decade or two. I suspect even this may not be enough to meet the growing demand. Now, human labeling for supervised learning is just one tiny tiny part of the overall AI enterprise. GAN technology will creep in just about everywhere, for content generation of images and much more, and you will need GAN’ers by the hundreds of thousands in a decade or more. Unsupervised learning technologies like GANs will eventually also employ potentially a million people. And so it goes. Every major application area of AI will generate millions of new jobs, and these are going to be in completely novel categories, job types that simply don’t exist today. So, take a deep breath, and stop worrying about AI killing jobs! Yes, undoubtedly some processes, perhaps many, will be more streamlined and result in fewer people required to do the same job, but the technology that made possible that streamlining will create many new jobs, perhaps far away geographically and require a different set of skills.

I feel compelled to answer this question, because I disagree with most of the answers here. The common answer here seems to be: yes it will kill jobs, but only the jobs low on the food chain, and it will create more jobs to at least offset the jobs it does kill. I disagree. I think AI will kill jobs, and over time, AI might kill most “jobs” as we know them. I think that people are somewhat complacent in regard to the economic impact of AI, and will likely be ill-prepared for the changes we have to adapt to in the not-so-distant future. First, let's start with the comparisons to machinery and automation. They did indeed put factory workers out of work. In that respect, I agree AI today is similar in many applications, replacing workers who have less specialized skills, perhaps call center operators, office assistants (in a limited extent), and maybe soon, taxi drivers and truck drivers. But I would argue that AI is fundamentally different from machinery or most of the other analogies commonly made when answering this question, because AI is growing and is unlikely to stop growing. It's growing in breadth (of applications and industries), in geographic and economic scope, and in power (it's capacity to address increasingly complex tasks). A more fitting analogy would be machinery in an automobile plant that not only made the parts one day, but then learned how to assemble them the week after, and then how to design cars a year later. I think that there is little that is out of reach for advanced AI of the future. Let's leave the question of the AI singularity alone for now. Instead, I think that deep learning efforts at Google and elsewhere are making AI systems learn faster and faster, with a growing rate of acceleration. Advanced AI can now address increasingly complex tasks including medical diagnosis, stock market trading, weather prediction and human behavioral modeling. Very soon, it will be able to take the place of certain types of teachers, and find a role in education. It can already deal with complex systems in software and mathematics, and seems to be only limited in applications that require interactions with the physical world (sensors are still imperfect), and with people. So without projecting too far into the future, we can ask the question, what jobs will NOT be killed by AI? Jobs that involve labor are already (or soon to be) replaced. Jobs that require logical reasoning are being replaced, albeit at a slower rate. What are the qualities that humans have that cannot be captured by AI? Perhaps creativity, emotional responses? So perhaps researchers in academia will survive longer than most, and artists (though AI stylistic mimicry is already quite impressive and their results enjoyable), and counselors/psychologists/case workers, and decision makers like CEOs who cannot be predictable or error prone. And hopefully software engineers and algorithm designers who develop AI systems. This leaves a very, very small portion of today's jobs intact. Many say: we just need to train people to fill higher level jobs created by AI, e.g. Programmers, ML researchers. But this is no easy feat. The US educational system is struggling to meet the demands created by advanced technology today. This failure is in part responsible for the economic divide plaguing the country today. The challenge of educating the public for a job market that is both decreasing in scope and increasing in complexity, is nothing we've ever faced before. I am far from original in this opinion. But if I had to guess, I would say that AI will put far more people out of work than we can (re)train in time. That will have significant economic repercussions as corporations seeking to minimize cost will do so at the cost of rising unemployment. There will need to be dramatic changes in social policies in order to avert large scale economic disaster, first dramatic rises in minimum wage, then eventually some type of universal income/welfare. It's the kind of change that requires significant leadership in our government, something that seems woefully absent today.

AI will likely create new and cause many existing jobs to change or in some cases disappear. The main thing to realize is that this is not a zero-sum game, and that there is no simple answer to the AI & jobs issue. Ai enhances creativity and renewal as much as job destruction. Some reports have projected a huge change with many manual and clerical jobs disappearing as AI learns to imitate repetitive, carefully circumscribed human job activities, such as entering data into computers, or selecting objects in different categories. On the whole these initial predictions (i.e. from 2012 to 2018) have been replaced by more measured analysis. Trends suggest that AI will act more as a help for humans in their jobs than as a replacement. This probably means that the type of jobs will vary more in future, with humans using various forms of machine intelligence (aka AI) to help them work faster, more productively and less wastefully in many cases. The fact is, AI cannot do most of the tasks involving complex judgments where a knowledge of the world and of human feelings, sympathy and understanding are of major importance. Oftne jobs we do not realize are so humanly-based. Any case in a job where moral or rational judgments are needed - where you have to weigh up the relative danger and benefits of some action for different types of people - will be both accessible to AI but probably protected from it because of the risk of error and lack of sympathetic intuition about what humans need. So humans may well find themselves in jobs that involve such skills as sympathy & care, evaluating who needs some benefit or treatment more than another, and how some decision for humans will have a long-term benefit or risk. In many cases we shall see jobs evolving in a way that enables AI to analyse lot of possibilities (because it can manipulate vast amounts of data quickly) and then leaving it to humans to make decisions, discuss with colleagues, reflect, and ask the machine to double check, etc. So overall, AI will change the way we do many jobs because it offers automation of highly mechanical tasks, and intellectual support for knowledge-based tasks. But as humans we naturally should not believe any of the human hype about machines “taking over” our jobs!

Why We Shouldn’t Be Scared Of Artificial Intelligence Replacing Everyone’s Jobs An interesting perspectiveThe big takeawayImplications for the enterpriseExamples of positive impact Enabling systemic change using AI to address biasCreating new kinds of job opportunitiesMaking workers more effective, efficient, and customer-centeredProviding personalized, satisfying work experiences that boost engagement and retentionAnswer In Detail-: A long time ago, Mark Twain wrote a note to a friend in which he apologized for not having time to write a shorter letter. In other words, Twain wished he’d had more time to think deeply and craft his message more succinctly. Life was slower back then – automation was just a glint in a futurist’s eye. In the digital age, my sentiment is along the same vein, but different: I’m sorry I didn’t have time to write you an even more thoughtful and insightful blog that adds more value to you as a reader. Time is always short, so if I’d had a digital assistant to do my research for me, I could have written a better, more insightful blog in less time. More of my time and effort could have been spent thinking more deeply and providing an even better answer to pressing questions like, “Are humans at war with the machines? Will automation and artificial intelligence (AI) take away our jobs – and the future of our children?” An interesting perspective Ten-time world chess master Garry Kasparov has an interesting perspective on this because he became the proverbial man in the first real “man-versus-machine” competition. In 1996, he played two matches against the IBM supercomputer Deep Blue, and he lost the second match. It was a crushing loss, and even he couldn’t help wondering, might this machine be invincible? Was he irrelevant now? And would people stop playing his beloved game because it had been conquered by a machine? The good news is none of these dreaded things happened. Chess has actually become more popular than ever, evolving to include advanced and freestyle forms where man + machine – or “augmented me” – has proven to be the winning combination. In a 1998 advanced chess competition, two amateur American chess players using three PCs coached their machines so successfully that they counteracted the superior chess knowledge of grandmasters and won the match. But the PCs couldn’t have won without the people. As Kasparov noted in his TED Talk: “Machines have calculations. We have understanding. Machines have instructions. We have purpose. Machines have objectivity. We have passion. We should not worry about what our machines can do today. Instead, we should worry about what they still cannot do today, because we will need the help of the new, intelligent machines to turn our grandest dreams into reality.” The big takeaway This story captures what most people who are afraid of AI don’t understand: even AI-enabled machines can’t actually replace people. That’s because machines can’t understand context and coordinate people and processes based on their understanding of that context. Only humans can understand and take into account things like interrelational dynamics, personality, organizational culture, attitudes and preferences, politics, moods, strategic visions, body language, and so much more. For instance, an understanding of context is needed for complex welding repairs (as opposed to repetitive welding in a manufacturing environment), such as those done by plumbers and oil rig workers; these workers need to take into account the age of assets, the weather, the type of pipes involved, and other factors – more than AI can handle. This is not to say that repetitive jobs will not be going away. They will – and sooner rather than later. Even highly paid people like accountants and actuaries should expect the number-crunching parts of their jobs to disappear. But humans will always be needed to provide insight into what those numbers mean, to weigh priorities and make optimal, context-informed decisions. We will increasingly rely on AI to augment us and do the busywork faster and more effectively (in my case, the grunt research for a blog) so we can do the higher-level work only humans can do. With their help, we’ll just do it faster, and with more and better data-driven insights to support those decisions. Implications for the enterprise Figure 1 nicely summarizes how I envision this trajectory of AI-augmented humans from an enterprise perspective. We’ll all do less repetitive work over time, freeing people to solve more problems, be more productive, make better decisions, and focus on more interesting and challenging activities like exploration, ideation, and innovation. These are things people do extraordinarily well – and deliver higher value to the enterprise.  Figure 1. How Automation Enables Humans to be More Productive and Focus on Tasks with Greater Value Examples of positive impact So what can we look forward to in practical terms? Well, we’re actually already seeing examples of positive impact from AI assistance. Let’s take a look at a few examples. Enabling systemic change using AI to address bias Consider Amazon’s recent attempt at automating the recruitment process. It wanted an intelligent system that could look at a collection of resumes and name the top candidates by analyzing the historical data of successful past hires. They eventually detected a problem – the data they had used to train the system reflected the tech industry’s dominance by men. So, AI was downgrading the resumes of women and people who attended women-only colleges, for instance, which perpetuated a hidden hiring bias. This may sound like a failure, but there’s more to it than that – it’s an incredible learning experience. AI revealed hidden bias that had plagued hiring at Amazon for years. And the project team has since modified the data used to train the AI to prevent such bias, thus ensuring HR and hiring managers don’t perpetuate unfair hiring practices going forward. Creating new kinds of job opportunities AI will create exciting new job opportunities – for example, where people act as trainers and explainers. Trainers will be used to train chatbots and digital assistants to offer more “human,” empathetic responses, recognize and respond to sarcasm, and more. Explainers will bridge the gap between humans and the systems augmenting them so people can interact with them more effectively and trust the data-driven recommendations provided by AI. They can also diagnose and fix errors made by AI so they aren’t perpetuated. Making workers more effective, efficient, and customer-centered AI can do more than just automate repetitive work. It can also anticipate needs and aggregate information instantly to make people more productive. For example, it can advise field technicians about which tools and replacement parts will be needed before heading to customer sites. It can provide intelligence about customers calling into a call center so agents are ready, have insights into what they may be calling about, and can provide faster, better service. Providing personalized, satisfying work experiences that boost engagement and retention The emerging workforce is growing up in a post-digital world that has raised its expectations in terms of “experience.” Employees expect tactile consumer experiences from enterprise software, personalized experiences, and work that is valued, engaging, and enriching – not paper pushing or similar grunt work. This is especially true for employees managing their HR tasks. AI is helping companies create these work experiences by providing self-service options that empower employees to take problem-solving into their own hands with solutions that are just as intuitive as the mobile apps they use in their personal lives. Looking ahead I’m looking forward to having a smart digital assistant join me so I can work smarter, faster, and more effectively. Are you?

I keep seeing this question, or its variants, and one has to get philosophical, asking — what is a job? Did the cavemen have jobs? They didn’t put on a suit, commute to an office, and talk about last night’s football game at the water cooler. Their “job” was just to find a way to exist. Sure, a stronger caveman may have been given a more militaristic assignment — protect the cave! — and a smarter one may have been a manager of sorts, but these were not jobs in a sense like we know them now.Which brings us to the Middle Ages. Surely, the serf had a job. He planted fields, tended to livestock. But again, it wasn’t 9-to-5. Did the nobility have jobs? The king? Again, what is a job?Which brings us to modern times. What would the caveman or the serf think of the guy who sits in a toll booth, the one who delivers newspapers, some guy in a bow tie who goes to a cubicle and types on a keyboard occasionally? Are they working?Are any of us working? Or are we really just running in circles? Are we all just passing time? So the robots come and they know how to hunter-gather and run a toll booth, etc. Then humans start planting rose bushes, they write poetry, they sail people around the lake on a boat. And they call these things jobs. We find ways to pass the time, and give them titles — so we feel we have purpose. Are these new jobs needed? How much do we pay a poet? A recreational sailor? (But does the caveman or the guy in the toll booth matter, really? How do we pay them?) Anyone who wants a job can have one — forever. Because a job is a perception — a perception that then creates a demand. As robots free up time, people will look to fill their own time, and, thus, “jobs” will be created — there now will be more demand for going around the lake on a boat, on having the prettiest rose bushes in town — maybe even some people now will want to hear that great poet read. And this new demand has currency. People will pay for it. And the poet will have pocket change now, and he will pay the sailor for a ride around the lake. Don’t be such rigid thinkers, everyone. A job is what you make of it.

There are two issues here. The first is that, by most measures, AI will be quite successful in knocking out jobs, one narrow vertical at a time. These will be more than the physical repetitive jobs that most people think a machine can do. Unlike prior technical revolutions, AI will actually hurt the highly specialized just as much as, or probably even more than the unspecialized workers. Truck Drivers and Customer Support workers aside, even highly specialized fields like Oncology, Dermatology, Music composition, Design and Immigration Law are all going to be upturned by AI. Note that this is independent of the “Singularity”. In past technical revolutions, the displaced workers who could be retrained were usually retrained for other jobs, in the process perhaps getting more specialized. But how do you retrain a highly specialized worker to begin with? The second issue is the time period over which the upheaval will occur. Older technological revolutions took decades to be widespread. This allowed capitalist societies to absorb the shock and provide enough alternatives to the people who had lost their jobs. In the case of the AI revolution, the upheaval is going to happen very quickly (my current prediction is 20 years given how well Moore’s law is working). Capitalist societies will be unable to absorb this shock. We’ve already seen the outcome of the automation in manufacturing upheaval (Trump) — I am afraid to imagine what will happen when 80% of the jobs are taken over by machines in the next 20 years. So what’s the solution? Radically transform education starting right now. Humans have to learn to be masters of the machines. We have to imagine a world where we can “manufacture” highly specialized workers at the click of a button. The only humans who will have a job in this world will be those who can navigate this world and constantly find ways of developing themselves past the point where a machine can threaten their livelihood.

That’s a good question, and the truth is, nobody really knows. Automation has been increasing for several years, and certainly many jobs previously done by humans are now done by machines. There have been estimates of the number of jobs which could be replaced by machines, and also estimates of how many jobs have actually been lost due to automation. The forecasts of potentially lost jobs have always been larger than the actual number. There are a few reasons for this. One is the expense of installing and maintaining a new machine is often more than the cost of paying the humans it replaces. Also, a robot can do only one specific task, and must be expertly reprogrammed to take on something new. Humans are much more flexible, not just in switching tasks, but in being paid only for the time that they are needed. Although automated machines can work 24 hours per day, they still need humans around to help out. AI will do jobs which need a human sitting at a computer, rather than assembling products or picking apples. However, the same factors apply, and no one really knows how many will actually be replaced by software. As well, AI can’t always do its job perfectly, and often only assists humans without replacing them. Any new technology has always created new jobs, though it’s hard to predict exactly how many. In the end there may be the same number of jobs lost as gained. The only thing we know for certain is there will be changes.

Yes. Unfortunately, more than most people are ready (and willing) to admit and accept. And it is not the AI’s fault. To predict AI’s impact on human jobs, one should understand, it is an economics question, not a technology question - this is VERY different than “when will AI become smarter than human” - AI does not need to be smarter than human to take most of the jobs. First, the economy, some argue historically, our innovations had created more job than it kills - look at from farming to urban, from product to services, etc. Well, to borrow a financial institution disclaimer - past performance does not indicate future result - let alone nothing close to AI was experimented historically speaking. Several blind spots in this view include: Generational shift - those historical innovations, while increased jobs over time, were mostly a job killer for the generation invented them. Replacing existing job is “lower hanging fruits” for technology, and usually are the first to happen; creating new jobs usually requires the technology to be digested well, and newer opportunities became viable after the technology’s long term impact is visible. This means majority of people who lose their job to technology would not find a better job in their lifetime, the beneficiaries are the future generations. This was true when we moved from agriculture to industrial, and it was true through the product to service shift as well - even now - American working class has not yet fully shift to service-oriented population, despite America benefited from being the birthplace of a majority of the modern innovation.Innovation speed - the generational shift problem was hidden in plain sight because innovation speed wasn’t significant, and the technology adoption rate is relatively low (compare to now). The impact to job market tent to be localized, and gradual (again, compared to now). This means people overall, have time to absorb the impact, recover and grow further.Population growth - Population growth had accompanied technology evolution historically, until now. Population growth used to be positive (demographically, more younger generation than older generation). This means those who would benefit from the technology will outnumber those who lose their jobs to technology. So instead of “technology creates more jobs”, it could very well be “technology enabled more people to adjust their lifestyle and generate more demand”. If you study economics, population growth is unspeakable important to economic, hence living-standard growth, and demand growth is THE driver of job growth.The social and family structure was able to provide some support that segregates this pain at the individual level - although the election of President Trump somewhat reminded people this individual level pain can pop up to collective level as well. The traditional family unit and community cooperation in Europe and Asia had supported people who lost their jobs, and because the larger economic unit, the shift from older generation to the younger generation is not as devastating as it is in modern America (and part of Europe)It is different this round, human society has entered into a new phase where birth rate, especially in developed economies where AI is more prominent, has dropped well below 2 children/couple for over a generation. It means the generational population dividend no longer exists - the benefit that newer generation who pick up new technology, and create more demand is not as it used to be — this factor does not even need AI to play out — this is just a social-economical change that any generational innovation will run into. Of course, there is also the higher innovation speed - previous innovation took several generations to pan out, now, AI could have several generational shifts within a generation (~40 years of typical individual working life). What does this mean? It means likely several generations will run into situations where a major proportion of which will lose their job before they retire even if they entered the job market in those “new jobs”. (Job’s “life expectancy” is shorter than human working life expectancy). Then there is the learning factor - the generational shift was mainly because it is “hard to train an old dog a new trick”. It is true, especially those who excel in old jobs for a long time, it will be very difficult to train them to be as good in new technology. So often happened was younger generation grew up to be proficient in new technology and take over the productivity. What people do not talk about often is every technical innovation increased training time required to master it. Current “service oriented” economy generally require 12 years of education - while in the traditional agriculture society 6 years of education is considered “a waste of time”. And we are talking about AI threatening jobs that require a post-secondary degree! What are the so-called “gold collar” jobs that lots of people proposed would be created? As a reference, Wall St. jobs typically require a post-graduate degree. And if you think working in the field of AI is harder than Wall St. jobs, you are correct, someone who can meaningfully take on AI jobs either as a researcher or practitioner commonly have 2–3 degrees. What does this mean? two things: 1) shifting to “new jobs” becomes harder and harder; 2) there are less and fewer people have the “job mobility”. Even if there are new jobs “Created” by AI, most people who lost their old jobs won’t be able to pick up newer jobs right away. So economic wise speaking, the feature of a new society taking on new innovation is different than previous technology revolutions. Irrespective of the type of the innovation, our society is *not* in a position to transition as smoothly as it used to be. Second, the technology, AI is different - very different. If you are interested in human history - you would notice that throughout documented history, all innovations have been “brain replace muscle”. Those who were strong and can carry loads of goods were not as important once a “smarty pants” invented wheels. Those who were harder working in the field were surpassed by those who pay attention to selecting best seeds, raw muscle power was further replaced by the steam engine, ICM, and so on — every turn of the human history, the power shifts from muscular to brainy. AND that is actually how we defined ourselves - “how human separated from the rest of the animals because we rely on our intellect to change the world we face”, our brain power is our “identity” among the living beings. Up to industrial revolution, this had been true - invented power sources took over raw muscle power, further enabling mental productivity. There were couple of “exceptions” to this though, and it could give us a taste of what is to come: When we invented writing, those oral storytellers retired from history (some tribe where writing was not as advanced actually retained storytellers), arguably, storytellers used to be one of few intellectual works back then - writing eliminated that as a role.When we started to design and create mechanical calculators (first by Da Vinci, then by Pascal, then Ada Lovelace and Charles Babbage), we started to get into “information processing automation” era. This might not look as “scary” at the beginning - after all, mechanical calculators were designed in the 1600s. nearly 400 years passed, no harm done.When we had electronics, and computers, “calculator” which used to be a job title, became the name of a small box with keys (then became an app, which is for later discussion). We now have invented something that replaces brain power - not just raw muscle power this time. Human calculators as a profession (a good paying one mind you) disappeared without much fuzz.Since then, we have changed our society so much that we can bearly survive without computers. However, this period of fast innovation also coincides with the globalization and the American’s shift from product to a service economy. But the social impact is hard to ignore - America to this day, still have generations of “victims of change” - while most economics cite globalization and shift to a service economy as the reason, the fact that technology was the enabler of both is undisputed. For the most part, the overall economic benefit to America had been positive. However, the list of disappeared (or significantly reduced) job categories quietly increases, telephone exchanger used to be a job, remember the girls pulling, plugging cords in front of a big electric panel? secretaries are virtually gone, other than very few “executive assistants” whose job is now threatened by Google Assistant, Siri, Alexa, and like, bookkeeper - which probably would hire 10x more people, was a niche now. Service jobs are not safe either - Online shopping, reduced jobs at retail, also reduced jobs in the warehouse. Uber reduced “fleet management”. Chatbot reduced call-centre agents. As you can see, the more “AI-ish” the technology innovation, the more “white-collar” job it replaces. But so far, these changes are “confined within certain industries”. While some argue that “human touch” is still not available from AI, it is kind of half-true — while AI can’t provide full spectrum of human touch, it can mimic a lot of emotional intelligence and “human-ish” reaction that trigger human-to-human kind of feelings. People have developed emotional attachment to objects since written history (probably earlier than that, but was not written down), and human’s emotional attachment to AI is very common and surprising — we don’t need AI to behave exactly like human before human accepts and adopts some level of “human-ish touch”. And that means as long as AI can provide sufficient level of emotion-like behavior, AI can take jobs even though it might not reach full “human’s level” Third, about new jobs that will be created That actually had been a myth that new technology always create new jobs - it is the increasing of population and increase of living-standard that create new jobs, not the technologies themselves. Technology always make doing things more efficient, so it takes less labor, or less resources, or offer better outcome - none of which will “require” net-more human effort — unless new demand (either quantity or quality of lives) are enabled by the new technology. As the world population reaching its capacity cap, population growth is not going to be the main economic (hence job creation) engine. The increase of living-standard on the otherhand might not work the same way as before either - as the carbon foot print becomes more and more important, and extreme poverty rate drops in the past 20 years, the pressure of energy consumption is increasingly become priority over increasing living-standards. This translates to lack of new job creation force. So expecting AI will create new jobs than it replaces is actually not concretely proven claim. Fourth, human value There are many ways for people to define value when it comes to human lives. My take on the *measureable* value can be found here: Human (Measurable) Value This does not cover all “value” that everyone might have for themselves, however, this covers something (cross-individual, measurable) way to discuss value. Basically it is a measure of desirability of an individual’s actions (or abilities when discussing future value). In other words, it means how much y ou can create some thing that will benefit other people - or they desire (when “beneficial” is not clearly defined). This is important - because when AI comes, most of the benefits and desires of human can be satisfied by AI at lower cost (resource-wise), meaning that the value human can create would significantly fade away. This round, AI is not just replacing jobs, it really replaces many people’s value — even if everyone is paid sufficient amount of money for nothing, what about humans’ desire of been perceived as “meaningful” — if I can’t do anything benefit other people at a cost effective way (i.e. maybe AI has a better and more efficient way to solve world hunger - by issuing free money to everyone, let’s say) what is the “reason for my existance”? So, the problem, not only does not have a “solution” (i.e. AI will create more jobs than it replaces), but also is actually much bigger than just jobs, it touches some of the very core concepts of the meaning of lives, jobs is just he tip of the iceberg most people “saw”.

Unless you consider super magic all powerful AI that will end humanity, the current wave of AI will have close to no impact on the job market. We will just get lots of fancy virtual toys for nearly nothing. Energy creates GDP. Then humans try to do something useful to get a share of the pie. AI will marginally help create more GDP as it has little impact on energy production. The pie will be more or less the same size. Then, humans will fight to provide something of value to get a share of the pie just as today. For example, in law firms. Today, you have 20 legal experts who search through case history. Tomorrow, better search engines will allow 3 legal experts to do the same work. But the goal is to win the lawsuit. And the law firm with 18 legal experts + search engine will win against the law firm with 3 legal experts + search engine. So in the end, you will have 18 legal experts + search engine and a licence of the law search engine and 2 employees in the law search engine corporation. Even more realistically, you will have 20 legal experts + search engine and the cost of the licence for the law search engine will replace the cost of the licence for various existing law softwares. In the end, the existing law software company will be replaced by an AI law software company and the jobs will just switch from a software company to a new software company. That’s pretty much the story of the last 20 years in tech. Software companies get replaced by new software companies every few years. Software features become integrated in open source libraries and you get it for free, then jobs move to a software company working on a new kind of feature that isn’t standardised yet. The AI revolution will just push a lot of software companies to bankruptcy to replace them with a lot of new software companies. That’s the story of growthless innovation, you replace an old company with a new one with a better technology. Then economists will dismiss AI innovation as being fake innovation because it as no impact on GDP and labour productivity (the two faces of the same coin). Economists will say “well, those new AI search engines were not real innovation, they didn’t increase the GDP generated by law firms who use those softwares”. What economists don’t understand is that only energy creates GDP growth, then the people fight each other for a piece of the pie. Law firms do nothing more that fighting each other for a share of the pie, they cannot create GDP. So you can do as much innovation as you want, this has an impact on which legal firm gets more of the pie, this has no impact outside of the legal industry. In other industries, AI will increase energy efficiency. Energy efficiency doesn’t create GDP either, it just increases the value of a unit of GDP. Energy efficiency frees energy that is used to get more of the same stuff. An extreme example is the microprocessor industry, they make processors with 1000000x the computation speed for the same price, but the total GDP captured by the microprocessor industry didn’t increase massively. This is the result of the extreme energy efficiency built into Moore’s law. An example of the AI revolution will be energy efficiency in last mile transportation. Delivery trucks are really inefficient, most of the weight of a delivery truck exists to transport the driver safely!  Starship.xyz is an example of what AI will do to last mile transportation. A city delivery van weights 2000kg and transports at most 200kg of packages (10x weight factor), a small delivery robot can weight 10kg and transport 5kg of packages (2x weight factor). That’s much more energy efficient. So we will get very cheap home delivery for the same amount of GDP Energy efficiency is how you end up with developing countries who have smartphones but still no drinkable tap water and reliable electricity grids. Because water and electricity systems are huge and require lots of energy and matter to build and maintain while smartphones are tiny and don’t consume much energy and matter. So to summarize, AI will provide powerful but useless tools in industry where the goal is to beat the opponent (law, marketing, lobbyism, HR and so on). AI will provide plenty of nearly free incredible virtual services. AI will provide some degree of energy efficiency and we will get more for the same amount of GDP. Overall, the effect of AI will be invisible in economic statistics and economists will say that this was just a fad. And to answer the question, it will have not much impact on the Indian IT industry. It will still be used as a subcontractor for big companies who want to upgrade their software to the previous fad. Once the new generation of big data becomes standardised enough and trendy startups all use it, massive and slow global conglomerates will ask Indian contractors to do the same AI thing for cheap for their products. In 2020, General Electrics will want generic AI things included in their software services and will ask Indian contractors to do it. Meanwhile, Silicon Valley 2015 AI startups will all go bankrupt as the 2020 trendy technology destroys 2015 AI startups. And in 2020, 30 years old software engineers who designed the 2015 AI startups when they were 25 years old will become employees of General Electics and supervise the subconctracting of 2015 technology to the Indian IT industry. (I don’t know if the Indian IT industry is moving up the value chain, this is in the case it keeps its current level. Inevitably so, I believe. Humans have two types of abilities—physical and cognitive. In the past, machines competed with humans mainly in raw physical abilities, while humans retained an immense edge over machines in cognition. Therefore, as manual jobs in agriculture and industry were automated, new service jobs emerged that required the kind of cognitive skills only humans possessed: learning, analyzing, communicating, and above all understanding human emotions. However, AI is now beginning to outperform humans in more and more of these skills, including in the understanding of human emotions. We don’t know of any third field of activity—beyond the physical and the cognitive—where humans will always retain a secure edge. It is crucial to realize that the AI revolution is not just about computers getting faster and smarter. It is fueled by breakthroughs in the life sciences and the social sciences as well. The better we understand the biochemical mechanisms that underpin human emotions, desires, and choices, the better computers can become in analyzing human behavior, predicting human decisions, and replacing human drivers, bankers, and lawyers. In the last few decades research in areas such as neuroscience and behavioral economics allowed scientists to hack humans, and in particular to gain a much better understanding of how humans make decisions. It turns out that our choices of everything from food to mates result not from some mysterious free will but rather from billions of neurons calculating probabilities within a split second. Vaunted “human intuition” is in reality “pattern recognition.” Good drivers, bankers, and lawyers don’t have magical intuitions about traffic, investment, or negotiation; rather, by recognizing recurring patterns, they spot and try to avoid careless pedestrians, inept borrowers, and sly crooks. It also turns out that the biochemical algorithms of the human brain are far from perfect. They rely on heuristics, shortcuts, and outdated circuits adapted to the African savannah rather than to the urban jungle. No wonder that even good drivers, bankers, and lawyers sometimes make stupid mistakes. This means that AI can outperform humans even in tasks that supposedly demand “intuition.” If you think AI needs to compete against the human soul in terms of mystical hunches, the task sounds impossible. But if AI really needs to compete against neural networks in calculating probabilities and recognizing patterns, that sounds far less daunting. In particular, AI can be better at jobs that demand intuitions about other people. Many lines of work—such as driving a vehicle in a street full of pedestrians, lending money to strangers, and negotiating a business deal—require the ability to correctly assess the emotions and desires of others. Is that kid about to run into the road? Does the man in the suit intend to take my money and disappear? Will that lawyer act upon his threats or is he just bluffing? As long as it was thought that such emotions and desires were generated by an immaterial spirit, it seemed obvious that computers would never be able to replace human drivers, bankers, and lawyers. For how could a computer understand the divinely created human spirit? Yet if these emotions and desires are in fact no more than biochemical algorithms, there is no reason computers cannot decipher these algorithms—and do so far better than any Homo sapiens. Will it be a better world or an apocalypse then? We’ll have to wait to find out. :)

Will AI kill jobs? Yes. Many jobs of today are in imminent danger of being automated. Many jobs aren’t, but that shouldn’t comfort you. An extra ten percent unemployment dramatically alters the political and economic realities of the country. We may be looking at a disruption as large as 47% in 20 years. Won’t humans work alongside AI rather than be replaced by it? This is the difference between a Complementary good and a Substitute good. Carriages and horses are complementary goods. Because they are capable of more together than separately, they increase each other’s value. This is not the relationship between a car and a horse or a delivery driver and a delivery drone. One obviates the need of the other; they are substitutes. The more AI becomes capable of, the more they will begin to substitute jobs rather than complement them. But it will create new jobs, right? Yes. It will create an increased demand for software developers, security specialists, coders that maintain legacy code and technicians who service machines. These, however, are high skilled jobs. In the past, automation has replaced low skilled jobs with low skilled jobs. Farmhands moved into factories. Factory workers moved to the service sector. Now automation will ask millions of middle aged drivers, cashiers, and telemarketers who can’t afford school, struggle with algebra and don’t know how to copy-and-paste to become programmers. How do you think that will unfold? But it will still create a net gain in jobs, right? Not necessarily. My city employs probably more than 500 bus drivers. If they were replaced by automated vehicles, do you suppose it would take 500 programmers or mechanics to deal with the added software and hardware maintenance? I think it might take <50. Will there be any jobs in the future? Yes, but not for you and me. In the near-term, jobs that are niche, high skill, or very variable will be safe from automation. Most people don’t have such jobs and can’t get them, so we will mostly be unemployed sometime this century. In the more speculative, distant future, there will only be jobs for emulated minds (EMs) and a few niche human careers. EMs will easily substitute for human labor and have the advantages of being infinitely copiable, being able to run as fast as a job requires, and market forces driving their wages down to subsistence levels. There will be jobs in the 2100s, but biological humans won’t have them. A rigorous, analytical exploration of this scenario can be found here.

Wow, strongly worded and straight to the point! Job extinction fueled by artificial intelligence (AI) is definitely a popular subject. It has been for quite a few years now. The media is absolutely obsessed with it -- fearmongering does wonders for ratings, I guess. But they’re not the only ones thinking about this hot topic. Researchers around the world are investigating possible implications, outcomes, and potential solutions. In fact, renowned economists Lukas Schlogl and Andy Sumner recently published a paper related to your question. I’ll save you some time. Here’s the conclusion: We are spending way too much time worrying if AI will take our jobs. Instead, we must focus on how it would actually do so, and how we can prepare for this scenario. Contrary to what the media headlines say once a week, AI won’t be instantly consuming every job available to humans. We won’t just be left to grovel at the feet of our AI overlords and praise them for another day that they allow us to live. The future is more nuanced than this simplistic perspective. Instead, expect to see a future where AI changes our jobs through a gradual and iterative process that spans the next few decades. Schlogl and Sumner had a great point with their paper. Let’s dig a little deeper into that concept: To understand how AI advancements will affect our future, we must understand how AI will affect our role in society. Don’t get me wrong -- AI will be extremely disruptive. Esteemed multinational consulting firm PwC has done a ton of research on the economics behind AI. They consider it “the biggest commercial opportunity in today’s fast-changing economy.” Those are some high expectations. Here’s why they said it: PwC expects AI to be responsible for 14 percent of global GDP growth by 2030. This value equals $15.7 trillion. That’s more than the current combined GDP output of China and India! Those are some astronomical figures. But remember, this change in value won’t happen overnight. In fact, PwC also projects that AI will affect society in three distinct phases. Each one will bring a new level of automation never seen before. PwC predicts that society will be disrupted by AI automation in three waves: Algorithm, Augmentation, and Autonomy. We’re actually in the Algorithm Wave right now, which is expected to last well into the early 2020s. Marked by the fact that AI’s still in its early stages, the majority of AI development during this time will be focused on digital tasks. Data analysis is the name of the game. Industries that rely on this, like finance, information, and communication, will feel the greatest impact. Per PwC, approximately 2 to 3 percent of the UK could be affected during the Algorithm Wave. After this, we’ve got the Augmentation Wave, which should end in the late 2020s. Finance will remain the main industry affected. But we’ll start to see a shift from digital tasks to more physical ones. Repeatable tasks like those you’d find in warehouse operations will get a massive revamp during this time. Low and medium education roles will be at a greater risk of disruption than their higher education counterparts as well. The Augmentation Wave could affect up to 20 percent of jobs. Go further into the near future, around the early 2030s, and we’ll find ourselves in the Autonomy Wave. This one will be defined by AI’s autonomous ability to analyze data, make decisions, and take action. No human help required. It will be the closest we’ve come to the AI we see in science fiction. Manual activities will bear the brunt of automation. Primary industries at risk during this time include manufacturing, retail, and transportation. Warehouses, factories, and stores will bear no resemblance to their current iterations. The Autonomy Wave could affect up to 30 percent of jobs. 44 percent of low-education roles will be at risk of being replaced. And there you have it. AI’s integration into our lives won’t be instantaneous but rather will resemble a piecemeal process. The times ahead may seem random and chaotic. But there is a method to AI’s madness. Let’s take a look at the finite number of ways AI can actually affect jobs. AI will only affect jobs in four ways: Destroy, Save, Augment, and Create. In the first category, we have jobs like customer service, delivery, and those you’d find in the fast food industry. All of these are susceptible to being replaced. And these roles are everywhere. So you can expect the media to bolster any fears people have during this time. But you’ll know better! You’ve read this Quora post, so you’ll be informed and have a clearer perspective of the times. Many jobs will actually be safe from AI disruption. There are some obvious ones, like the people creating and maintaining the AI. These people will actually be thriving. Because of their high level of skills, they’ll be highly rewarded. Creative roles such as R&D, design, and product management will also be protected from AI’s wrath. Military jobs and contractors will also be relatively okay due to the fact that robots won’t be able to do every part of their job. AI will take over the more mundane aspects of many roles. But highly skilled guilds like handymen and electricians will still be needed to complete complex tasks out of AI’s reach. Here’s a category you don’t hear often in relation to AI: Religion. I’d venture to say that spiritual leaders will remain human. People who have faith in a higher being won’t be wanting an AI giving a sermon or carrying out sacred traditions any time soon. Now, let’s move on to the third category. AI will also augment many roles. Like religion, we probably still won’t be comfortable with AI piloting our planes, even 30 years from now. Similar to our discussion of contractors, AI autopilot will take care of the mundane, everyday aspects of flying. But human pilots will be on standby to take over if need be. Expect to see this sort of streamlined relationship across various industries. But besides physical tasks, AI will also help with many mental tasks. Information-heavy fields such as law, medicine, and accounting will receive a big boost in decision-making thanks to AI. In one way or another, practically everyone will benefit from AI’s inhuman ability to synthesize sharp insights from colossal amounts of data. Last but not least, AI will also surprisingly create new jobs! Many new roles will be directly related to the AI industry itself. But the disruptive technology will also make way for new avenues across all industries. Unfortunately, this is difficult to predict at the moment due to the fact that AI will restructure numerous value chains. And that about wraps this up. Artificial Intelligence – its origin and evolution  It was mathematician and scientist Alan Turing who spent a lot of time after the Second World War on devising the Turing Test. Though it was basic, this test involved evaluating if it was possible for artificial intelligence to hold a realistic conversation with a person, thus convincing them that they were also human. Since Turing’s Test, AI was restricted to fundamental computer models. It was in 1955 when John McCarthy – a professor at MIT, coined the term “artificial intelligence”. During his tenure at MIT, he built an AI laboratory. Full List Processing (LISP) was developed by him there. LISP was a computer programming language for robotics intended to provide expansion potential as technology improvements happened with time. Though promise was shown by some base model machines – be it Shakey the Robot (1966) or Waseda University’s anthropomorphic androids WABOT-1 (1973) and WABOT-2 (1984), it wasn’t until 1990 when Rodney Brooks revitalized the concept of computer intelligence. But it took many more years for artificial intelligence to evolve as it was only in 2014 that Eugene, which was a chatbot program designed by the Russians, was able to successfully convince 33% of human judges. According to Turing’s original test, more than 30% was a pass, though plenty of room was left for stepping it up in the future. From its humble beginnings, artificial intelligence (AI) has evolved as perhaps the most significant technological advancement in recent decades across all industries. Be it the robotics aspect of AI, or the implementation of machine learning (ML) technologies that are driving useful insights from big data, the future seems to hold a lot of promise. In fact, the enhanced information extracted from large chunks of data is helping companies today to mitigate supply chain risks, improve customer retention rates, and do a lot more. An example of how these technologies could change the way we live and work became evident when Amazon introduced its Alexa in the workplace. However, many believe that the AI-powered, voice-activated device signals just the beginning. Thanks to NLP (natural language processing), which is made possible via machine learning, modern computers, hi-tech systems, and solutions can now know the context and meaning of sentences in a much better way. As NLP becomes more improved and refined, humans will start communicating with machines seamlessly exclusively via voice without the need of writing code for a command. Thus, professionals who can design and test devices based on NLP and voice-driven interactions are likely to be in high demand in the future. With the growing interest and implementation of artificial intelligence in various fields and the promising future the global machine learning market (predicted to grow to $8.8B by 2022 from $1.4B in 2017, according to a report by Research and Markets), there’s bound to be a wide variety in future jobs for data science professionals as well those specializing in AI and ML.
